# Distribution of wealth

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

The **distribution of wealth** is a comparison of the [wealth](/wiki/Wealth
"Wealth") of various members or groups in a [society](/wiki/Society
"Society"). It differs from the [income
distribution](/wiki/Income_distribution "Income distribution") in that it
looks at the [economic distribution](/wiki/Distribution_\(economics\)
"Distribution \(economics\)") of ownership of the [assets](/wiki/Asset
"Asset") in a society, rather than the current income of members of that
society. The distribution of wealth shows [economic
differences](/wiki/Economic_inequality "Economic inequality") as per the [Gini
index](/wiki/Gini_coefficient "Gini coefficient").

## Definition of
wealth[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Distribution_of_wealth&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Definition of wealth")]

Main article: [Wealth](/wiki/Wealth "Wealth")

Wealth in the context of this article is defined as a person's net worth,
expressed as:

    [wealth](/wiki/Wealth "Wealth") = [assets](/wiki/Asset "Asset") − [liabilities](/wiki/Liability_\(financial_accounting\) "Liability \(financial accounting\)")

The word _wealth_ is often confused with _[income](/wiki/Income "Income")_.
These two terms describe different but related things. Wealth consists of
those items of economic value that an individual owns, while income is an
_inflow_ of items of economic value. (See [Stock and
flow](/wiki/Stock_and_flow "Stock and flow").) The relation between wealth,
income, and expenses is:

    change of wealth = income − expense.

The distribution of income is substantially different from the distribution of
wealth. According to the International Association for Research in Income and
Wealth, "the world distribution of wealth is much more unequal than that of
income."[1]

If an individual has a large income but also large expenses, the net effect of
that income on her or his wealth could be small or even negative.

The [United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations") definition of
_inclusive wealth_ is a monetary measure which includes the sum of natural,
human and physical assets.[2][3]

## Data about global distribution of
wealth[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Distribution_of_wealth&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Data about global distribution of wealth")]

Main articles: [List of countries by distribution of
wealth](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_distribution_of_wealth "List of countries
by distribution of wealth") and [List of countries by income
equality](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_income_equality "List of countries by
income equality")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b8/Share_of_wealth_globally.png/220px-
Share_of_wealth_globally.png)](/wiki/File:Share_of_wealth_globally.png)

[](/wiki/File:Share_of_wealth_globally.png "Enlarge")

Share of wealth globally by year[4]

The gap between the rich and poor can be illustrated by the fact that the
three wealthiest individuals in the world have assets that exceed those of the
poorest 10 percent of the world's population.[5] The net worth of [the world's
billionaires](/wiki/Billionaire "Billionaire") increased from less than $1
trillion in 2000 to over $7 trillion in 2015 so the gap is growing up
dramatically.

### Wealth distribution
pyramid[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Distribution_of_wealth&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Wealth distribution pyramid")]

Personal wealth varies across adults for many reasons. Some individuals with
little wealth may be at early stages in their careers, with little chance or
motivation to accumulate assets. Others may have suffered business setbacks or
personal misfortunes, or live in parts of the world where opportunities for
wealth creation are severely limited. At the other end of the spectrum, there
are individuals who have acquired a large fortune through a combination of
inheritance, talent, hard work or simply being in the right place at the right
time. The wealth pyramid below was prepared by [Credit
Suisse](/wiki/Credit_Suisse "Credit Suisse") in 2013; it captures these
differences in striking detail. It has a large base of low wealth holders,
alongside upper tiers occupied by progressively fewer people. In 2013 Credit-
suisse estimate that 3.2 billion individuals – more than two thirds of adults
in the world – have wealth below 10,000 USD. A further one billion(adult
population) fall within the 10,000 – 100,000 USD range. While the average
wealth holding is modest in the base and middle segments of the pyramid, their
total wealth amounts to USD 40 trillion, underlining the potential for novel
consumer products and innovative financial services targeted at this often
neglected segment.[6]

  
The pyramid reveals that:

  * half of the world's wealth belongs to the top 1%,
  * top 10% of adults hold 85%, while the bottom 90% hold the remaining 15% of the world's total wealth,
  * top 30% of adults hold 97% of the total wealth.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/9/96/Distribution_of_wealth_globally.jpg)](/wiki/File:Distribution_of_wealth_globally.jpg)

Pyramid of global wealth distribution in 2013[6]

#### Wealth distribution in
2012[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Distribution_of_wealth&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Wealth distribution in 2012")]

According to the OECD in 2012 the top 0.6% of world population (consisting of
adults with more than 1 million USD in assets) or the 42 million richest
people in the world held 39.3% of world wealth. The next 4.4% (311 million
people) held 32.3% of world wealth. The bottom 95% held 28.4% of world wealth.
The large gaps of the report get by the Gini index to 0.893, and are larger
than gaps in global income inequality, measured in 2009 at 0.38.[7] For
example, in 2012 the bottom 60% of the world population held same wealth in
2012 as the people on Forbes' Richest list consisting of 1,226 richest
billionaires of the world.

## Statistical
distributions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Distribution_of_wealth&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Statistical distributions")]

There are many ways in which the distribution of wealth can be analyzed. One
example is to compare the wealth of the richest one percent with the wealth of
the median (or 50th) percentile. In many societies, the richest ten percent
control more than half of the total wealth.

_[Pareto Distribution](/wiki/Pareto_distribution "Pareto distribution")_ has
often been used to mathematically quantify the distribution of wealth, since
it models a random distribution.

_Wealth over people (WOP) curves_ are a visually compelling way to show the
distribution of wealth in a nation. WOP curves are modified distribution of
wealth curves. The vertical and horizontal scales each show percentages from
zero to one hundred. We imagine all the households in a nation being sorted
from richest to poorest. They are then shrunk down and lined up (richest at
the left) along the horizontal scale. For any particular household, its point
on the curve represents how their wealth compares (as a proportion) to the
average wealth of the richest percentile. For any nation, the average wealth
of the richest 1/100 of households is the topmost point on the curve (people,
1%; wealth, 100%) or (p=1, w=100) or (1, 100). In the real world two points on
the WOP curve are always known before any statistics are gathered. These are
the topmost point (1, 100) by definition, and the rightmost point (poorest
people, lowest wealth) or (p=100, w=0) or (100, 0). This unfortunate rightmost
point is given because there are always at least one percent of households
(incarcerated, long term illness, etc.) with no wealth at all. Given that the
topmost and rightmost points are fixed … our interest lies in the form of the
WOP curve between them. There are two extreme possible forms of the curve. The
first is the "perfect communist" WOP. It is a straight line from the leftmost
(maximum wealth) point horizontally across the people scale to p=99. Then it
drops vertically to wealth = 0 at (p=100, w=0).

The other extreme is the "perfect tyranny" form. It starts on the left at the
Tyrant's maximum wealth of 100%. It then immediately drops to zero at p=2, and
continues at zero horizontally across the rest of the people. That is, the
tyrant and his friends (the top percentile) own all the nation's wealth. All
other citizens are serfs or slaves. An obvious intermediate form is a straight
line connecting the left/top point to the right/bottom point. In such a
"Diagonal" society a household in the richest percentile would have just twice
the wealth of a family in the median (50th) percentile. Such a society is
compelling to many (especially the poor). In fact it is a comparison to a
diagonal society that is the basis for the [Gini
values](/wiki/Gini_coefficient "Gini coefficient") used as a measure of the
disequity in a particular economy. These Gini values (40.8 in 2007) show the
United States to be the third most dis-equitable economy of all the developed
nations (behind Denmark and Switzerland).

More sophisticated models have also been proposed.[8]

## Redistribution of wealth and public
policy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Distribution_of_wealth&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Redistribution of wealth and public policy")]

See also: [Redistribution of income and
wealth](/wiki/Redistribution_of_income_and_wealth "Redistribution of income
and wealth") and [Distribution of wealth in year
2000](/wiki/Distribution_of_wealth_in_year_2000 "Distribution of wealth in
year 2000")

In many societies, attempts have been made, through [property
redistribution](/wiki/Property_redistribution "Property redistribution"),
[taxation](/wiki/Taxation "Taxation"), or [regulation](/wiki/Regulation
"Regulation"), to [redistribute](/wiki/Redistribution_\(economics\)
"Redistribution \(economics\)") wealth, sometimes in support of the upper
class, and sometimes to diminish [economic
inequality](/wiki/Economic_inequality "Economic inequality").

Examples of this practice go back at least to the [Roman
republic](/wiki/Roman_republic "Roman republic") in the third century B.C.,[9]
when laws were passed limiting the amount of wealth or land that could be
owned by any one family. Motivations for such limitations on wealth include
the desire for equality of opportunity, a fear that great wealth leads to
political corruption, to the belief that limiting wealth will gain the
political favor of a [voting bloc](/wiki/Voting_bloc "Voting bloc"), or fear
that extreme concentration of wealth results in rebellion.[10] Various forms
of [socialism](/wiki/Socialism "Socialism") attempt to diminish the unequal
distribution of wealth and thus the conflicts and social problems (see image
below) arising from it.[11]

During the [Age of Reason](/wiki/Age_of_Reason "Age of Reason"), [Francis
Bacon](/wiki/Francis_Bacon "Francis Bacon") wrote "Above all things good
policy is to be used so that the treasures and monies in a state be not
gathered into a few hands… Money is like fertilizer, not good except it be
spread."[12]

[Communism](/wiki/Communism "Communism") arose as a reaction to a distribution
of wealth in which a few lived in luxury while the masses lived in [extreme
poverty](/wiki/Extreme_poverty "Extreme poverty"). In _[The Communist
Manifesto](/wiki/The_Communist_Manifesto "The Communist Manifesto")_ ,
[Marx](/wiki/Karl_Marx "Karl Marx") and [Engels](/wiki/Frederick_Engels
"Frederick Engels") wrote "[From each according to his ability, to each
according to his
need](/wiki/From_each_according_to_his_ability,_to_each_according_to_his_need
"From each according to his ability, to each according to his need")."[13]
While the ideas of Marx have nominally been embraced by various states
(Russia, Cuba, Vietnam and China in the 20th century), Marxist utopia remains
elusive.[14]

On the other hand, the combination of [labor movements](/wiki/Labor_movements
"Labor movements"), [technology](/wiki/Technology "Technology"), and [social
liberalism](/wiki/Social_liberalism "Social liberalism") has diminished
extreme poverty in the [developed world](/wiki/Developed_world "Developed
world") today, though extremes of wealth and poverty continue in the [Third
World](/wiki/Third_World "Third World").[15]

In the Outlook on the Global Agenda 2014 from the [World Economic
Forum](/wiki/World_Economic_Forum "World Economic Forum") the widening income
disparities come second as a worldwide risk.[16][17]

## Wealth
surveys[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Distribution_of_wealth&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Wealth surveys")]

Many countries have national wealth surveys, for example:

  * The British [Wealth and Assets Survey](http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/guide-method/method-quality/specific/economy/wealth-and-assets-survey/wealth-and-assets-survey---user-guidance/index.html)
  * The Italian [Survey on Household Income and Wealth](/wiki/Survey_on_Household_Income_and_Wealth "Survey on Household Income and Wealth")
  * The euro area [Household Finance and Consumption Survey](https://www.ecb.europa.eu/pub/economic-research/research-networks/html/researcher_hfcn.en.html)
  * The US [Survey of Consumer Finances](/wiki/Survey_of_Consumer_Finances "Survey of Consumer Finances")
  * The Canadian [Survey of Financial Security](http://www5.statcan.gc.ca/bsolc/olc-cel/olc-cel?lang=eng&catno=13F0026MIE2006001)
  * The German [Armuts- und Reichtumsbericht der Bundesregierung](http://www.armuts-und-reichtumsbericht.de/DE/Startseite/start.html)

## 21st
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Distribution_of_wealth&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: 21st century")]

At the end of the 20th century, wealth was concentrated among the
[G8](/wiki/G8 "G8") and Western [industrialized
nations](/wiki/Industrialized_nations "Industrialized nations"), along with
several [Asian](/wiki/Asia "Asia") and [OPEC](/wiki/OPEC "OPEC") nations.

### Wealth
inequality[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Distribution_of_wealth&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Wealth inequality")]

A study by the [World Institute for Development Economics
Research](/wiki/World_Institute_for_Development_Economics_Research "World
Institute for Development Economics Research") at United Nations University
reports that the richest 1% of adults alone owned 40% of global assets in the
year 2000, and that the richest 10% of adults accounted for 85% of the world
total. The bottom half of the world adult population owned 1% of global
wealth.[18] Moreover, another study found that the richest 2% own more than
half of global household [assets](/wiki/Asset "Asset").[19]

### Real
estate[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Distribution_of_wealth&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Real estate")]

While sizeable numbers of households own no land, few have no income. For
example, 10% of land owners (all corporations) in [Baltimore,
Maryland](/wiki/Baltimore,_Maryland "Baltimore, Maryland") own 58% of the
taxable land value. The bottom 10% of those who own any land own less than 1%
of the total land value.[20] This form of analysis as well as [Gini
coefficient](/wiki/Gini_coefficient "Gini coefficient") analysis has been used
to support [land value taxation](/wiki/Land_value_taxation "Land value
taxation").

## In the United
States[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Distribution_of_wealth&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: In the United States")]

See also: [Wealth inequality in the United
States](/wiki/Wealth_inequality_in_the_United_States "Wealth inequality in the
United States"), [Income inequality in the United
States](/wiki/Income_inequality_in_the_United_States "Income inequality in the
United States"), and [Wealth in the United
States](/wiki/Wealth_in_the_United_States "Wealth in the United States")

<div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;

![Circle
frame.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Circle_frame.svg/200px-
Circle_frame.svg.png)

Distribution of net worth in the United States (2007). The net wealth of many
people in the lowest 20% is negative because of debt.[22]

Top 1% (35%)

Next 4% (27%)

Next 5% (11%)

Next 10% (12%)

Upper Middle 20% (11%)

Middle 20% (4%)

Bottom 40% (<1%)

According to [PolitiFact](/wiki/PolitiFact "PolitiFact"), in 2011 the 400
wealthiest Americans "have more wealth than half of all Americans
combined."[23][24][25][26] [Inherited wealth](/wiki/Inherited_wealth
"Inherited wealth") may help explain why many Americans who have become rich
may have had a "substantial head start".[27][28] In September 2012, according
to the [Institute for Policy Studies](/wiki/Institute_for_Policy_Studies
"Institute for Policy Studies"), "over 60 percent" of the [Forbes richest 400
Americans](/wiki/Forbes_400 "Forbes 400") "grew up in substantial
privilege".[29]

In 2007, the richest 1% of the American population owned 34.6% of the
country's total wealth (excluding human capital), and the next 19% owned
50.5%. The top 20% of Americans owned 85% of the country's wealth and the
bottom 80% of the population owned 15%. From 1922 to 2010, the share of the
top 1% varied from 19.7% to 44.2%, the big drop being associated with the drop
in the stock market in the late 1970s. Ignoring the period where the stock
market was depressed (1976–1980) and the period when the stock market was
overvalued (1929), the share of wealth of the richest 1% remained extremely
stable, at about a third of the total wealth.[30] Financial inequality was
greater than inequality in total wealth, with the top 1% of the population
owning 42.7%, the next 19% of Americans owning 50.3%, and the bottom 80%
owning 7%.[31] However, after the [Great Recession](/wiki/Great_Recession
"Great Recession") which started in 2007, the share of total wealth owned by
the top 1% of the population grew from 34.6% to 37.1%, and that owned by the
top 20% of Americans grew from 85% to 87.7%. The Great Recession also caused a
drop of 36.1% in median household wealth but a drop of only 11.1% for the top
1%, further widening the gap between [the 1%](/wiki/The_1%25 "The 1%") and
[the 99%](/wiki/The_99%25 "The 99%").[22][30][31] During the economic
expansion between 2002 and 2007, the income of the top 1% grew 10 times faster
than the income of the bottom 90%. In this period 66% of total income gains
went to the 1%, who in 2007 had a larger share of total income than at any
time since 1928.

[Dan Ariely](/wiki/Dan_Ariely "Dan Ariely") and Michael Norton show in a study
(2011) that US citizens across the political spectrum significantly
underestimate the current US wealth inequality and would prefer a more
egalitarian distribution of wealth, raising questions about ideological
disputes over issues like taxation and welfare.[32]

qa.question: who owns 50 percent of the worlds wealth

m.07jwr_288.Query Analysis: The query asks about the ownership of a significant portion of the world's wealth, specifically who owns 50 percent of it.
m.07jwr_288.Answer Analysis: The answer indicates that the top 1% of the population owns 50 percent of the world's wealth.
m.07jwr_288.Document Content Analysis: The document discusses the transmission of infections through saliva and air, the asymptomatic nature of most infections, the development of diseases from latent infections, and the mortality rate if untreated.
m.07jwr_288.Document and Query Keywords Matching: None of the query keywords ('owns', '50 percent', 'world's wealth') are found in the document.
m.07jwr_288.Document and Answer Keywords Matching: None of the answer keywords ('top 1%') are found in the document.
m.07jwr_288.Key Information Matching: There is no key information in the document that matches the query or the answer. The document focuses on medical and health-related topics, which are unrelated to wealth distribution.
m.07jwr_288.Can the Document Answer the Query: No, the document does not contain any information about wealth distribution or ownership.
